title: How to Install a Drop Ceiling

steps.title: Measure the length of each wall in your room.
steps.content: Measure the length of each wall in your room. Use a tape measure to find the length of each wall in the room where you’re installing your ceiling. Write the dimensions of your room either in a notebook or directly on the wall 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) from the top so you can easily reference them later. [1] X Research source If your room is square or rectangular, you only need to measure the length and width.

steps.title: Make a line between 4–6 in (10–15 cm) down from the tops of your walls.
steps.content: Make a line between 4–6 in (10–15 cm) down from the tops of your walls. Leave at least 4–6 in (10–15 cm) of space from the top of your wall to your line so you have room for fixtures and to put in your tiles. Use a 4 ft (1.2 m) level and draw a straight line with your pencil completely around your room. [2] X Research source Snap a chalk line if you don’t want to draw the lines on yourself. Hold the string of the chalk line against your wall and snap it so the line transfers onto the drywall. If you plan on installing a large fluorescent light panel, make your line 6 in (15 cm) down.

steps.title: Use a pair of tin snips to cut wall angles to the lengths of your walls.
steps.content: Use a pair of tin snips to cut wall angles to the lengths of your walls. Wall angles are long L-shaped pieces used around the walls of your room to support the tiles and runners. Since wall angles are usually sold in 8–12 ft (2.4–3.7 m) lengths, trim them down with your tin snips to match the lengths of your walls. [3] X Research source If you have a corner that juts out from your wall, cut the wall angles going on those walls 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) longer than your measurements. If you want a mitered finish in the corners, cut the wall runner bottom-most wall angle at a 45-degree angle. If your walls are longer than the wall angles, butt 2 of them together by lining up the ends.

steps.title: Screw the wall angles into the studs along the line you drew.
steps.content: Screw the wall angles into the studs along the line you drew. Use a stud finder to locate the studs in your walls and mark their locations with a pencil. Line up the top of the wall angle with the line you’ve drawn on the wall. Use 1 1 ⁄ 4 in (3.2 cm) screws and electric screwdriver where you marked the studs to secure your wall angles in place. [4] X Research source Double check that your wall angles are level as you install them.

steps.title: Cut the main runners to fit the length of your room perpendicular to the joists.
steps.content: Cut the main runners to fit the length of your room perpendicular to the joists. The main runners will support the bulk of the weight of your ceiling. Measure the length of your room that runs perpendicular to the wooden joists of your ceiling. Cut the runners with a pair of tin snips to the correct length. [5] X Research source If your room is longer than the length of a main runner, use the clips on the ends of the piece to attach them together.

steps.title: Use a chalk line or tie strings across your room every 4 ft (1.2 m).
steps.content: Use a chalk line or tie strings across your room every 4 ft (1.2 m). Secure the end of a chalk line on one end of your room and pull it tight to the other side. Snap the chalk line to leave a line on the joists. Move over 4 ft (1.2 m) and make another line on your ceiling. Keep moving across your room until you reach the other edge. [6] X Research source You may also tie strings tight across your ceiling if you don’t have a chalk line.

steps.title: Screw an eyelet into every third joist along your line.
steps.content: Screw an eyelet into every third joist along your line. Eyelet screws have holes on the end so you can run wires through them to hang your main runner. Attach a lag bit onto your electric screwdriver, and set an eyelet inside the bit. Start placing your eyelets 3 joists away from the wall along each of your chalk or string lines. Keep adding an eyelet at every third joist. [7] X Research source Eye lit screws can be purchased from your local hardware store.

steps.title: Feed a length of wire through each of the eyelets.
steps.content: Feed a length of wire through each of the eyelets. Cut a 8–10 in (20–25 cm) piece of 16-gauge wire for each of your eyelets. Feed about 2 in (5.1 cm) of the wire through the eyelet, and bend it with a pair of pliers until it points down. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Hang up the main runners by the wires.
steps.content: Hang up the main runners by the wires. Hold one of your main runners up so the ends rest on your wall angles and so it’s perpendicular to your joists. Feed the other end of the wire through one of the circular slots on the runner, and bend it up with your pliers. Twist the wires around themselves at least 3 times to keep them secure. [9] X Research source Make sure your joists are level as you keep adding wires. Adjust where the bend is in the wires if one side is higher than the other.

steps.title: Install the secondary runners perpendicular to your mains by clipping them in place.
steps.content: Install the secondary runners perpendicular to your mains by clipping them in place. Locate the slots on the main runners every 2 ft (0.61 m). Lift your 4 ft (1.2 m) runners above the main runners and feed them into the slots on the mains. Put a secondary runner every 2 ft (0.61 m) along your main runners. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Make holes in the tiles for any lighting or ductwork first.
steps.content: Make holes in the tiles for any lighting or ductwork first. Locate any areas on your ceiling where you need to make an opening for your ducts or light fixtures. Trace the end of the duct or the size of the light feature onto the back of one of your tiles. Cut the shape out of the tile with a sharp utility knife. [11] X Research source If you’re installing a full-panel fluorescent light fixture, you don’t need to cut any shapes from the tiles.

steps.title: Trim any edge tiles
steps.content: Trim any edge tiles down to size with a utility knife. Your room will most likely have edges that won’t fit full-sized tiles. Measure the grid opening for the tile and add 3 ⁄ 8 in (0.95 cm) to the measurement you found. Transfer that measurement to tile and cut the piece to size using a utility knife. [12] X Research source Avoid using any power equipment to cut your tiles since it will generate a lot of dust.

steps.title: Cut out a 3⁄8 in (0.95 cm) flange in any cut edge of your tiles.
steps.content: Cut out a 3 ⁄ 8 in (0.95 cm) flange in any cut edge of your tiles. The flanges rest on your runners and make the tile have more dimension when you put it in your ceiling. Measure in 3 ⁄ 8 in (0.95 cm) from any edge that doesn’t have a flange and draw a line with a pencil. Follow along the line with a utility knife, only cutting halfway through the tile. Make another cut on the side of the tile at the same depth as your first cut to remove the flange piece. [13] X Research source This only needs to be done if your tiles don’t have flanges already.

steps.title: Lift the tiles through the grid and set them on top of the grid.
steps.content: Lift the tiles through the grid and set them on top of the grid. Start in the center of your room and work towards the edges. Angle the tiles and lift them through the grid system. Straighten the tiles out before setting the flanges on the runners. Continue putting the tiles into your ceiling until it’s completely covered. [14] X Research source Make sure the tiles are level as you install them. If you find any that aren’t level, adjust the runners before moving on.
